awd_titl_txt: A New View of the Chemical Evolution of Nearby Galaxies with Keck and VLT Integral Field Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
As stars evolve, they produce and distribute heavy elements (i.e. elements heavier than helium) into the interstellar gas.  Over time, the heavy element content builds up in a galaxy, increasing the metallicity of the gas.  Metallicity has an important role in governing how galaxies form new stars. Metallicity can also change because of inflow of gas from the galaxy's surroundings and outflows of gas from the galaxy disk caused by intense bursts of star formation. Once it is in a galaxy, gas with varying metallicity is mixed together by turbulence and flows.  The local metallicity in a galaxy therefore reflects the competition between all of these factors.  These investigators will study the region-to-region variation of metallicity in nearby galaxies to learn about how these important processes shape the heavy element content of galaxies.  The PI will also lead a program of professional development and mentoring for incoming transfer students to the physical sciences at UC San Diego with the goal of increasing their participation in undergraduate research.  

The investigators will make the next critical step forward in measuring ISM metallicities in nearby galaxies using new integral field spectroscopic observations performed with the Keck Cosmic Web Imager (KCWI) and the Very Large Telescope Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (VLT-MUSE). These instruments will obtain high sensitivity, fully-sampled maps of the 3500-9300 Angstrom optical spectrum allowing detailed metallicity studies using temperature-sensitive auroral emission lines of oxygen, nitrogen and sulfur. Previous studies have been limited in their assessment of metallicity due the faintness of the spectral lines needed for accurate metallicity diagnostics. The investigators will use the KCWI and MUSE observations to study metallicity inhomogeneity as a function of galaxy properties such as morphology, specific star formation rate and presence of a stellar bar and they will compare these observations to predictions from galaxy simulations and theory. To broaden participation in science, the PI will lead a series of workshops for transfer students in the physical sciences at UC San Diego to provide training in research skills and guidance in finding research positions. The PI will also initiate organized data collection to track the career path of transfer students. This dataset will be used to assess the effectiveness of the program and develop further strategies for increasing the fraction of underrepresented minorities who pursue advanced degrees in the physical sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we investigated the variation of the heavy element abundance (also called "metallicity") in the interstellar medium of nearby galaxies. The degree to which the metallicity varies from place to place depends on how quickly and efficiently the ISM is mixed together and how much of the metals newly created by stars are expelled from the galaxy's disk by stellar winds and supernova explosions. To measure the metallicity, we used two of the most powerful "integral field spectrographs" in the world, one on the Keck telescope (KCWI) and one on the Very Large Telescope (MUSE). The data from KCWI and MUSE together let us observe a set of faint emission lines that come from the regions of ionized gas around young, massive stars.  These faint emission lines allow us to measure the temperature of the gas, which we must know in order to accurately measure metallicity. Using our observations, we were able to measure the temperatures of several hundred regions in nearby galaxies.  With so many temperatures, we were able to statistically characterize how the temperature of the gas depends on galactic environment.  One important thing we learned is that the most highly ionized gas in a region appears to show a distinct temperature in many cases from the less ionized gas. We found that the temperature difference between more vs less ionized gas correlated with the properties of the surrounding molecular clouds in a way that suggests winds or supernovae from the massive stars may be creating very hot, highly ionized gas and stirring up turbulence in the surrounding interstellar medium.  

Over the course of this project, we were also able to study one of the lowest metallicity galaxies in the nearby Universe, called I Zw 18. Our KCWI observations of I Zw 18 revealed three locations in the galaxy with extremely highly ionized gas, revealed by the existence of doubly ionized helium.  Gas this highly ionized is difficult to explain because normal stars don't get hot enough to ionize gas to that degree (unless current models of stars are incomplete, which is definitely possible).  We found that all three doubly ionized helium regions lay along the same line, which intersects with the position of an "ultra-luminous x-ray source" (ULX) near the center of the galaxy.  Past studies have suggested that this source is what powers the central ionized nebula.  The two additional regions we found complicate that picture, particularly one of them which appears to be outside the main part of the galaxy without young stars nearby, suggesting that the gas is not ionized by something local.  We investigated the possibility that the doubly ionized helium in all three regions of I Zw 18 comes from beamed emission or jets from the central ULX.  If this is the case, it may be that some of the other galaxies where highly ionized gas is observed may also have ULX's powering their emission.

Over the course of this project, we also worked on an effort to involve more community college transfer students in undergraduate research.  California has an amazing system for students to transfer from community college to University of California institutions, like UC San Diego (where the PI works).  These students are frequently first generation college students and/or face financial challenges in going to college.  Many transfer students in STEM fields aim to continue on to graduate school after college, but due to the compressed time they have at their UC institution, they face challenges in obtaining the undergraduate research experience that is often needed for competitive graduate admissions.  Over the last four years, the PI has run a workshop for new transfer students at the start of their junior year to gain key skills needed in undergraduate research (reading academic papers, applying for research opportunities, programming, computer skills, and more).  The first two years of the project focused on Physics transfer students. In the last two years the program expanded to all Physical Sciences at UCSD. The program reached 20-30 students per year and was well received. The knowledge gained in this program is now being put to use in designing efforts to reach future transfer students while they are still at their community college and get them access to research projects immediately after they arrive at their UC institution.
